*[Bug 18888] pchisq(0,0) returns 0, not 1*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18888>

--- Comment #2 from Robert Schlicht (<mailto:robert.schlicht@tu-dresden.de|robert.schlicht@tu-dresden.de>) ---
I just had a look at edge cases of several other distributions that represent
point masses at zero. On my system, the following all return F(0)=1, consistent
with the standard textbook definition F(x) = Pr(X <= x) of the cumulative
distribution function:
```
pnorm(0, mean=0, sd=0)              # 1
punif(0, min=0, max=0)              # 1
pbeta(0, shape1=0:3, shape2=Inf)    # 1
pbinom(0, size=0:3, prob=0)         # 1
pbinom(0, size=0, prob=c(0,0.25,1)) # 1
ppois(0, lambda=0)                  # 1
pnbinom(0, size=0:3, mu=0)          # 1
pnbinom(0, size=0, prob=c(0.25,1))  # 1
```
The point masses at 1/2 and 1 for the beta distribution that you showed also
follow that convention.

So the outlier is really the gamma distribution, including the special case of
the chi-squared distribution:
```
pgamma(0, shape=0, scale=1:3)       # 0
pchisq(0, df=1:3)                   # 0
```

This would correspond to the definition F(x) = Pr(X<x), which I have seen in
some mostly older books like Kolmogorov's Grundbegriffe. Mathematically the
conditions Pr(X=x) = 0 and Pr(X<=x) = Pr(X<x) are both equivalent to continuity
of F at x (i.e., no jump at x). So for (non-degenerate) continuous
distributions there is no issue at all since both definitions coincide.

The case `pgamma(0,0)==0` is explicitly handled in the code found at the end of
`<https://svn.r-project.org/R/trunk/src/nmath/pgamma.c>`, and there is a comment:
"limit case; useful e.g. in pnchisq()". Probably it should not be changed.
Maybe this is a solution:

1. In the description of the `lower.tail` parameter of `pgamma`, replace the
phrase "P[X<=x], otherwise, P[X>x]" with "P[X<x], otherwise, P[X>=x]" since
that seems to be what is happening. (There is another degenerate case,
`scale=0`, which would also imply a point mass at zero, but `pgamma` does not
handle this anyway.)

2. In the description of the `lower.tail` parameter for `pchisq`, add a
reference to `pgamma` for the central case.

The double precision representation of real numbers is a tricky issue. One
could argue that at `0`, which actually represents a small interval around
zero, the distribution function is not precisely defined anyway. I expect,
though, that for the point mass at zero, which is a discrete distribution, `0`
would most often mean exactly zero (such as an empty sum); many other functions
such as `sign` treat it that way. At the same time, the processors I am
familiar with distinguish a positive and negative zero (note that `1/0==Inf`
and `1/-0==-Inf`), which is finer than the standard mathematical concept and
might suggest F(-0)=0 and F(+0)=1 for the point mass at zero. But the
distinction is probably just a device for helping with some computations
involving divisions; I guess I should not be relied on, and most functions,
including `==`, do not distinguish between `+0` and `-0` (or they handle it in
creative ways, like `sqrt(-0)` returning a negative zero).

*[Bug 18892] Support the use of netrc when using the libcurl downloader?*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18892>

Eric Lindblad (<mailto:lindblad@gmx.com|lindblad@gmx.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |lindblad@gmx.com

--- Comment #3 from Eric Lindblad (<mailto:lindblad@gmx.com|lindblad@gmx.com>) ---
Stenberg's Post

`<https://daniel.haxx.se/blog/2022/05/31/netrc-pains/>`

Notwithstanding that people are unlikely to write code absent community
interest in such feature request.

Exmh uses q-agent; which doesn't run on Microsoft Windows and/or the Cygnus
port.

Someone could look at the above programs and write code to store secrets.

GTK is needed for some q-agent convenient functionality (including
secret-on-demand).

Something similar to the GTK1 code could be written in Tk.

A GUI could open preloaded with partial though modifiable information but not
the passphrase.

Debian repositories might have copies of the aforementioned programs' source
code.
